keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a major theft of historic royal jewelry, including items from Napoleon, Empress Eugénie, and other French royalty, during a 7-minute heist in the Apollo Gallery.
The stolen items include a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace from Napoleon’s wedding gift to Marie-Louise, and several brooches and diadems from Empress Eugénie’s collection.
One of the most valuable items, Eugénie’s diamond-encrusted reliquary brooch, was recovered near the scene, though damaged.
The heist is described as a 'national disaster' by art recovery expert Arthur Brand, due to the historical, cultural, and symbolic value of the stolen artifacts.
The jewelry has deep historical roots, with some pieces tracing back to Queen Marie Antoinette or King Louis XIV, and some having been passed through generations of royal families.
The theft threatens not only the physical integrity of these objects but also France’s cultural heritage, as these pieces represent national pride and identity.
The recovery of the crown near the scene indicates that the thieves may have attempted to dismantle or melt down the gold and silver, suggesting a plan to sell or recycle the materials.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris on October 20, 2025, where four thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes and stole nine historically significant royal artifacts, including a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace from Napoleon’s wedding gift to Marie-Louise, and several brooches from Empress Eugénie. These items, dating from the early 19th century to the 1850s, are deeply tied to French imperial history and craftsmanship. The stolen jewelry is described by experts as a 'national disaster' due to its cultural and symbolic value. One of the most valuable pieces, Eugénie’s reliquary brooch, was partially recovered near the scene, though damaged. The heist has sparked international concern over the security of cultural heritage, and experts believe the thieves may have dismantled the items to melt down the gold and silver. The items have provenance through royal families, jewelers, and private collectors, including Van Cleef & Arpels and the Smithsonian. The theft represents a profound loss to France’s cultural identity and raises urgent questions about museum security and the global protection of historical artifacts.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
